intro: Maquira guianensis subsp. guianensis, commonly known as the Guianan maquira, is a large, evergreen tree native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the family Moraceae, which includes figs and mulberries, and is characterized by its robust trunk and broad, palmate leaves. The tree produces a distinctive, fibrous fruit that is often used in traditional medicine and local crafts. It thrives in humid, lowland rainforest environments and plays a significant role in the ecological structure of its habitat. Due to its economic and ecological value, it is also a focus of conservation efforts in its native range.
